orangelight.title: Display links to Hathi Trust items if they are available

comments.body:
Users who are not logged in to Hathi will see a message that the item is "not available online"
![Screen Shot 2020-04-01 at 8 42 55 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/856924/78138406-d9b5b480-73f4-11ea-814f-ffcccc8c950e.png)

Maybe we should send them to the login URL instead of to the item URL?

Since this is throw away...

The plan is to override the show in catalog controller: https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/blob/master/app/controllers/catalog_controller.rb#L634

The controller will call a helper service to create the url

if the url is set in the controller we will show a new partial in the availability: https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/blob/04d9ae4f1aea6da5547a0bacf59d3b97ab7c5b28/app/views/catalog/_show_availability.html.erb

To complete this we need to:

- [ ] HathiUrlService input: solr document output: hathi url
- [ ] Override catalog controller show to run the service
- [ ] change _show_availability to display a partial if the url is set
- [ ] create the partial to show the url

login link with target:
https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/wayf?target=https%3A%2F%2Fbabel.hathitrust.org%2Fcgi%2Fpt%3Fid%3Dmdp.39015047450062
One issue that came up — we may want to exclude SCSB records, because we think their holdings wouldn't be counted, and therefore our users wouldn't be given access.
Yes we noticed SCSB records are not available.

pulfalight.title: Ensure that all parent containers are indexed

comments.body:
Reviewing the work committed in https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/pull/212, `dsc[2]` elements were actually getting indexed, and I misunderstood the original scope of this issue.

Currently, `components` are indexed within the top-level `collection` Solr Documents. This should document this and clearly outline how to access collection components.

I do not believe that `components` have child `components` within them indexed. That might need to be addressed for this as well.

https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/commit/7064c7b95d464b9334cec6eb30c28e38b12a0577 seems to be the only proper approach which I could find for recursively processing child components of component elements (`<c>`).

Recursively nested components are definitely indexed right now. There's a clipboard system that keeps track of parent nodes, and the `//` selector makes sure the selection is arbitrarily deep. It's just that they're indexed as top level components with a field that says where in the hierarchy they are.
I was indexing components within the `components` field of the Solr Document with this approach, as I could only find this field populated for top-level collections.
More generally, I am honestly uncertain if this is even necessary to implement. I might close this issue in favor of another issue within https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/issues/159
After discussing this with @hackmastera, I am incorrect, and this is still needed in order to ensure that the parent components are accessible for batch requests submitted to the Aeon API.
The nested components were indeed not being indexed, I will offer a PR off of my work-in-progress branch for this.

pulfalight.title: Ensures that nested child components are nested within component Solr Documents

comments.body: I sort of wonder if they weren't nested deeply on purpose for some reason? It seems like it was probably a choice to put them all at the parent level. Maybe someone knows?
